description: From modern Latin vibratiuncula,  diminutive form of Latin vibrātio (“vibration”).

entries.meaning: (now chiefly historical) A minuscule or slight vibration; specifically, a vibration in brain tissue caused by the comparatively greater vibrations of the particles of the medullary substance of the nerves (formerly hypothesised to convey external impressions to the mind). [from 18th c.]
examples: Diminutive Vibrations, which may also be called Vibratiuncles and Miniatures.
